tit.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya) Fushimi Sadanaru
Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya) Fushimi Sadanaru
tit.cmt: 修正なし
tit.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya) Fushimi Sadanaru
tit.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 伏見宮貞愛親王（ふしみのみや さだなるしんのう、安政5年4月28日 (旧暦)（1858年6月9日） - 大正12年（1923年）2月4日）は、日本の皇族、大日本帝国陸軍軍人。
sen.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya) Fushimi Sadanaru was (June 9th, 1858 to February 4th, 1923) a Japanese Imperial family and a member of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA).
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru (Fushiminomiya Sadanarushinno) was (June 9, 1858 to February 4, 1923) a Japanese Imperial family and a member of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA).
sen.cmt: 日付表記を既定に沿って変更し、（ふしみのみや さだなるしんのう)の読みを入れました。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru (Fushiminomiya Sadanarushinno) was (June 9, 1858 to February 4, 1923) a Japanese Imperial family and a member of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA).

sen.j: 伏見宮邦家親王第14王子、母は鷹司政熙の女鷹司景子。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the fourteenth son of the Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, and his mother was Ms. Hiroko TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Mr. Masahiro TAKATSUKASA.
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the fourteenth son of the Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, and his mother was Hiroko TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Masahiro TAKATSUKASA.
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the fourteenth son of the Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, and his mother was Hiroko TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Masahiro TAKATSUKASA.

sen.j: 伏見宮第22代および第24代。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the 22nd successor of the Fushimi no Miya family; at a later time, would become the 24th successor of the Fushimi no Miya family.
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the 22nd successor of the Fushimi no Miya family; at a later time, would become the 24th successor of the Fushimi no Miya family.
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the 22nd successor of the Fushimi no Miya family; at a later time, would become the 24th successor of the Fushimi no Miya family.

sen.j: 官位は元帥 (日本)陸軍大将菊花章金鵄勲章内大臣。
sen.e: The official court rank of the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was general in the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA), Orders of the Chrysanthemum, received the Golden Pheasant Kunsho (Medal), and Minister of the Interior.

The official court rank of the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was general in the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA), Orders of the Chrysanthemum, received the Golden Pheasant Kunsho (Medal), and Minister of the Interior.

The official court rank of the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was general in the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA), Orders of the Chrysanthemum, received the Golden Pheasant Kunsho (Medal), and Minister of the Interior.

tit.e: Biography
Biography
tit.cmt: 修正なし
tit.e: Biography
tit.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 幼名は敦宮。
sen.e: In childhood the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went by the name of 'Atsu no Miya.'
In childhood the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went by the name of 'Atsu no Miya.'
In childhood the Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went by the name of 'Atsu no Miya.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 親王は始め妙法院を相続したのち孝明天皇の養子となる。
sen.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) first became the successor of the Myoho-in Temple, and then later, he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) first became the successor of the Myoho-in Temple, and then later, he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.
Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) first became the successor of the Myoho-in Temple, and then later, he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.

sen.j: しかし、伏見宮貞教親王薨去のため、文久2年（1862年）11月に還俗し家督を継ぐ。
sen.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) returned to secular life because of Kokyo (death of a man of upper than Third Rank) of the Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Sadanori, then Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) returned to secular life because of Kokyo (death of a man of upper than Third Rank) of the Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Sadanori, then Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya.

Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) returned to secular life because of Kokyo (death of a man of upper than Third Rank) of the Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Sadanori, then Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya Sadanaru) took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）いったん伏見宮を離れ家督を父宮の邦家親王に渡す。
sen.e: In 1864, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru once separated from the Fushiminomiya and returned in headship to the family of his father Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie.
In 1864, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru once separated from the Fushiminomiya and returned in headship to the family of his father Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie.
In 1864, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru once separated from the Fushiminomiya and returned in headship to the family of his father Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie.

sen.j: そして明治5年（1872年）再度伏見宮を継承し第24代となる。
sen.e: Then, once again in '1872' Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya becoming the 24th successor of the family.
Then, once again in 1872, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya becoming the 24th successor of the family.
sen.cmt: シングルクォートを削除しました。
sen.e: Then, once again in 1872, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru took over as head of the family of Fushiminomiya becoming the 24th successor of the family.

sen.j: 親王は皇族として唯一内大臣府を務め、軍人として最高位の元帥 (日本)陸軍大将に就任した。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the only member of the Imperial family who served at the Minister of Interior's Office, or to be assigned as the highest ranking officer in the Japanese Imperial Army, that of general.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the only member of the Imperial family who served at the Minister of Interior's Office, or to be assigned as the highest ranking officer in the Japanese Imperial Army, that of general.

Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was the only member of the Imperial family who served at the Minister of Interior's Office, or to be assigned as the highest ranking officer in the Japanese Imperial Army, that of general.

sen.j: そのほか、大日本農会・大日本蚕糸会・在郷軍人会・理化学研究所・済生会等の総裁を歴任する。
sen.e: Furthermore, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru successively worked in and held positions in multiple organizations, such as a president of the Dai Nihon Nokai (Japanese National Agricultural and Farmers Association), The Dai Nihon Silk Foundation (Japanese National Silk Foundation), The Zaigo Gunjinkai (The Association of Reservists), RIKEN, Saiseikai (currently, "Social Welfare Organization Saiseikai Imperial Gift Foundation Inc.") and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru successively worked in and held positions in multiple organizations, such as a president of the Dai Nihon Nokai (Japanese National Agricultural and Farmers Association), The Dai Nihon Silk Foundation (Japanese National Silk Foundation), The Zaigo Gunjinkai (The Association of Reservists), RIKEN, Saiseikai (currently, "Social Welfare Organization Saiseikai Imperial Gift Foundation Inc.") and others.

Furthermore, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru successively worked in and held positions in multiple organizations, such as a president of the Dai Nihon Nokai (Japanese National Agricultural and Farmers Association), The Dai Nihon Silk Foundation (Japanese National Silk Foundation), The Zaigo Gunjinkai (The Association of Reservists), RIKEN, Saiseikai (currently, Social Welfare Organization Saiseikai Imperial Gift Foundation Inc.) and others.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: なお、済生会の総裁職はのちに寛仁親王が就任する。
sen.e: Additionally, at a later time, the Imperial Prince Tomohito took the office of president of Saiseikai.
Additionally, at a later time, the Imperial Prince Tomohito took the office of president of Saiseikai.
Additionally, at a later time, the Imperial Prince Tomohito took the office of president of Saiseikai.

sen.j: 親王は馬術・囲碁・音楽・弓術・撞球・書道・書画刀剣・木石花卉などを趣味とした。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru had hobbies in many fields such as the Japanese horse-back archery technique, Igo (board game of capturing territory), music, the art of Japanese archery, billiards, Shodo (calligraphy), application or collection of art works (calligraphic works, paintings, and swords), gardening enthusiast (trees, stones, and flowing plants), and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru had hobbies in many fields such as the Japanese horse-back archery technique, Igo (board game of capturing territory), music, the art of Japanese archery, billiards, Shodo (calligraphy), application or collection of art works (calligraphic works, paintings, and swords), gardening enthusiast (trees, stones, and flowing plants), and others.

Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru had hobbies in many fields such as the Japanese horse-back archery technique, Igo (board game of capturing territory), music, the art of Japanese archery, billiards, Shodo (calligraphy), application or collection of art works (calligraphic works, paintings, and swords), gardening enthusiast (trees, stones, and flowing plants), and others.

sen.j: そのため、銚子犬吠埼の別邸・瑞鶴荘には矢場・撞球場が設けられた（『貞愛親王逸話』）。
sen.e: Thus, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru set up a Yaba (archery range) place and a place for playing billiards, this was in his second residence the Zuikakuso Villa, located in Inubosaki, Choshi City ["Sadanaru Shinnou Itsuwa (The Anecdote of Imperial Prince Sadanaru)"].
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Thus, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru set up a Yaba (archery range) place and a place for playing billiards, this was in his second residence the Zuikakuso Villa, located in Inubosaki, Choshi City ("Sadanaru Shinnou Itsuwa [The Anecdote of Imperial Prince Sadanaru]").

Thus, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru set up a Yaba (archery range) place and a place for playing billiards, this was in his second residence the Zuikakuso Villa, located in Inubosaki, Choshi City ("Sadanaru Shinnou Itsuwa [The Anecdote of Imperial Prince Sadanaru]").
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

tit.e: Career
Career
tit.cmt: 修正なし
tit.e: Career
tit.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年） 誕生、敦宮と命名
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was borne in '1858' and then named, 'Atsu no Miya' (Prince Atsu).
Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was born in 1858 and then named, 'Atsu no Miya' (Prince Atsu).
sen.cmt: borne→bornの誤字訂正, シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was born in 1858 and then named, Atsu no Miya (Prince Atsu).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年） 妙法院相続、孝明天皇養子
sen.e: In '1860', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became the successor of Myoho-in Temple, and some time later he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.
In 1860, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became the successor of Myoho-in Temple, and some time later he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1860, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became the successor of Myoho-in Temple, and some time later he was adopted by the Emperor Komei.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年） 伏見宮復籍・継承（第22代）
sen.e: In '1862', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru returned to the 'Fushimi no Miya' family and then became the successor of 'Fushimi no Miya' (The twenty second).
In 1862, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru returned to the Fushimi no Miya family and then became the successor of Fushimi no Miya (The twenty second).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1862, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru returned to the Fushimi no Miya family and then became the successor of Fushimi no Miya (The twenty second).

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年） 伏見宮を離れる
sen.e: In '1864', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru left the 'Fushimi no Miya' family.
In 1864, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru left the Fushimi no Miya family.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1864, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru left the Fushimi no Miya family.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年） 親王宣下、元服 諱を貞愛と賜り二品に叙せられる
sen.e: In '1871', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was given the title of Imperial Prince and then given the real name of "Sadanaru," for his genpuku (to celebrate one's coming of age) ceremony, and was given the Imperial court ranking of nihon (the second court rank for an Imperial Prince).

In 1871, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was given the title of Imperial Prince and then given the real name of "Sadanaru," for his genpuku (to celebrate one's coming of age) ceremony, and was given the Imperial court ranking of nihon (the second court rank for an Imperial Prince).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1871, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was given the title of Imperial Prince and then given the real name of Sadanaru, for his genpuku (to celebrate one's coming of age) ceremony, and was given the Imperial court ranking of nihon (the second court rank for an Imperial Prince).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 明治5年（1872年） 東京へ移住、伏見宮継承（第24代）
sen.e: In '1872', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved to Tokyo and became the successor of 'Fushimi no Miya' (The twenty fourth).
In 1872, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved to Tokyo and became the successor of Fushimi no Miya (The twenty fourth).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1872, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved to Tokyo and became the successor of Fushimi no Miya (The twenty fourth).

sen.j: 明治6年（1873年） 陸軍幼年学校入学
sen.e: In '1873', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered the Army Cadet School.
In 1873, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered the Army Cadet School.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1873, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered the Army Cadet School.

sen.j: 明治8年（1875年） 陸軍士官学校 (日本)入学、第一王子博恭王誕生
sen.e: In '1875', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered The Imperial Japanese Army Academy; it was at this time his first prince (son) was born, named "Prince Hiroyasu."
In 1875, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered The Imperial Japanese Army Academy; it was at this time his first prince (son) was born, named "Prince Hiroyasu."
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1875, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru entered The Imperial Japanese Army Academy; it was at this time his first prince (son) was born, named Prince Hiroyasu.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 明治9年（1876年） 有栖川宮熾仁親王の妹・利子女王と結婚
sen.e: In '1876', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru married Imperial Princess Arisugawa Toshiko, a sister of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.
In 1876, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru married Imperial Princess Arisugawa Toshiko, a sister of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1876, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru married Imperial Princess Arisugawa Toshiko, a sister of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.

tit.j: 明治10年（1877年） 西南戦争に出征
tit.e: In '1877', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went to the war front during The Satsuma Rebellion (Seinan War).
In 1877, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went to the war front during The Satsuma Rebellion (Seinan War).
tit.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
tit.e: In 1877, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru went to the war front during The Satsuma Rebellion (Seinan War).
tit.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 明治11年（1878年） 陸軍大尉に昇進、陸軍士官学校出仕
sen.e: In '1878', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru received the promotion to captain in the Imperial Army, and then attended The Imperial Japanese Army Academy.
In 1878, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru received the promotion to captain in the Imperial Army, and then attended The Imperial Japanese Army Academy.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1878, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru received the promotion to captain in the Imperial Army, and then attended The Imperial Japanese Army Academy.

sen.j: 明治12年（1879年） （神田区西小川町、麹町区富士見を経て）麹町紀尾井町4番地に転居
sen.e: In '1879', (After relocation to the Nisi Ogawa-Machi in Kanda Ward and then Fujimi in the Kojimachi Ward) Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved into this house address, at number four, Kioi-cho, Kojimachi, Tokyo.
In 1879, (After relocation to the Nisi Ogawa-Machi in Kanda Ward and then Fujimi in Kojimachi Ward) Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved into this house address, at Kioi-cho 4, Kojimachi, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: シングルクオート、スペース、定訳に沿った番地箇所の書き方に変更しました。
sen.e: In 1879, (After relocation to the Nisi Ogawa-Machi in Kanda Ward and then Fujimi in Kojimachi Ward) Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru moved into this house address, at Kioi-cho 4, Kojimachi, Tokyo.

sen.j: 明治13年（1880年） 博愛社（後の日本赤十字社）社員
sen.e: In '1880', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was employed by the Philanthropic Society (in Japanese, "Hakuaisha"; Later, it became "the Japanese Red Cross Society").
In 1880, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was employed by the Philanthropic Society (in Japanese, "Hakuaisha"; Later, it became "the Japanese Red Cross Society").
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1880, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was employed by the Philanthropic Society (in Japanese, Hakuaisha; Later, it became the Japanese Red Cross Society).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 明治14年（1881年） 陸軍歩兵少佐に昇進、大日本山林会総裁
sen.e: In '1881", Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted the rank of major in the infantry of the Imperial Army; he then became the president of The Dai Nihon Sanrinkai (The Japan Forestry Association).

In 1881, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted the rank of major in the infantry of the Imperial Army; he then became the president of The Dai Nihon Sanrinkai (The Japan Forestry Association).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1881, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted the rank of major in the infantry of the Imperial Army; he then became the president of The Dai Nihon Sanrinkai (The Japan Forestry Association).

sen.j: 明治16年（1883年） 亜細亜協会名誉会員、東京地学協会名誉会員
sen.e: In '1883', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was appointed to the position of honorary memberships in the Asia Kyokai (Asian Association) and Tokyo Chigaku Kyokai (Tokyo Geographical Society).
In 1883, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was appointed to the position of honorary memberships in the Asia Kyokai (Asian Association) and Tokyo Chigaku Kyokai (Tokyo Geographical Society).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1883, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was appointed to the position of honorary memberships in the Asia Kyokai (Asian Association) and Tokyo Chigaku Kyokai (Tokyo Geographical Society).

tit.j: 明治17年（1884年） 陸軍歩兵中佐に昇進
tit.e: In '1884', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.
In 1884, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.
tit.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
tit.e: In 1884, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.
tit.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 明治19年（1886年） 大勲位菊花大綬章受章
sen.e: In '1886;, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was elevated to the position of Grand Cordon in the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum (In Japanese, "Daikuni Kikkasho"; the highest Cordon and Honor in Japanese citizenry).

In 1886, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was elevated to the position of Grand Cordon in the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum (In Japanese, "Daikuni Kikkasho"; the highest Cordon and Honor in Japanese citizenry).
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1886, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was elevated to the position of Grand Cordon in the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum (In Japanese, Daikuni Kikkasho; the highest Cordon and Honor in Japanese citizenry).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 明治20年（1887年） 女子教育奨励会（のちの東京女学館）会員。
sen.e: In '1887', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became a member of the Joshi Kyoiku Shorei Kai (Institution for Women Education in Japan; Later, "Tokyo Jogakkan Schools for Women").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1887, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became a member of the Joshi Kyoiku Shorei Kai (Institution for Women Education in Japan; Later, "Tokyo Jogakkan Schools for Women").
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1887, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru became a member of the Joshi Kyoiku Shorei Kai (Institution for Women Education in Japan; Later, Tokyo Jogakkan Schools for Women).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除

sen.j: 近衛歩兵第4連隊長、任陸軍歩兵大佐。
sen.e: Then, he was promoted to Imperial Guard infantry fourth division regimental commander, holding the post of colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then, he was promoted to Imperial Guard infantry fourth division regimental commander, holding the post of colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.
Then, he was promoted to Imperial Guard infantry fourth division regimental commander, holding the post of colonel in the infantry of the Imperial Army.

sen.j: 伏見宮邸で天覧試合、「最後の剣客」榊原鍵吉による兜割りを観覧。
sen.e: In the same year, a game was held with the Emperor in attendance at the 'Fushimi no Miya' estate; there he watched a Mr. Kenkichi SAKAKIBARA, "The Last Expert Swordsman," perform the "Kabuto Wari (helmet cutting)."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the same year, a game was held with the Emperor in attendance at the Fushimi no Miya estate; there he watched a Kenkichi SAKAKIBARA, "The Last Expert Swordsman," perform the Kabuto Wari (helmet cutting).
sen.cmt: シングルクオート、ダブルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In the same year, a game was held with the Emperor in attendance at the Fushimi no Miya estate; there he watched a Kenkichi SAKAKIBARA, 'The Last Expert Swordsman,' perform the Kabuto Wari (helmet cutting).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 明治22年（1889年） 陸軍少将に昇進、第3回内国勧業博覧会総裁。
sen.e: In '1889', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of major general of Imperial Army, that same year he became a president of The Third National Industrial Exhibitions.
In 1889, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of major general of Imperial Army, that same year he became a president of The Third National Industrial Exhibitions.
sen.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
sen.e: In 1889, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was promoted to the rank of major general of Imperial Army, that same year he became a president of The Third National Industrial Exhibitions.

tit.j: 明治23年（1890年） 貴族院 (日本)に列席。
tit.e: In '1890', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru presented to at The House of Peers of Japan (In Japanese, "Kizokuin").
In 1890, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru presented to at The House of Peers of Japan (In Japanese, "Kizokuin").
tit.cmt: シングルクオートの変更しました。
tit.e: In 1890, Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru presented to at The House of Peers of Japan (In Japanese, Kizokuin).

tit.j: 明治25年（1892年） 京都美術協会総裁、日本体育会名誉賛成員。

sen.j: 陸軍少将・歩兵第4旅団長。

tit.e: In '1884', Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru was assigned to the Liaodong Peninsula, commanding the battle for Kinshujo castle, during Japanese-Sino War.

tit.e: In '1896', in the position of representative for the Emperor Meiji, Prince Sadanaru attended the enthronement ceremony for the Russian Emperor Nicholai II, as the official representative of the Emperor Meiji.

sen.j: 陸軍大将、大本営附、米国へ出発。

sen.j: 瑞鶴荘の竣工、軍事参議官。

sen.j: 同地の日系人社会に200ドルを下賜（これを基金として後に「伏見宮記念奨学会」を設立）。

Brothers: Imperial Prince Yamashina no Miya Akira, Imperial Prince Shogoin no Miya Yoshikoto, Imperial Prince Manshuin no Miya Jonin Nyudo, Imperial Prince Kuni no Miya Asahiko, son, Imperial Prince Fushimi no Miya Sadanori, son, Imperial Prince Komatsu no Miya Akihito, Imperial Prince Kitashirakawa no Miya Yoshihisa, son, son, Imperial Prince Kacho no Miya Hirotsune, Imperial Prince Kitashirakawa no Miya Satonari, Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Sadanaru, Ienori KIYOSU, Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Kotohito, and Imperial Prince Higashifushimi no Miya Yorihito (daughters were omitted)

sen.j: 妻：貞愛親王妃利子女王（有栖川宮幟仁親王王女） - 女房河野千代子 - 女房增山奈越子
sen.e: Wife: Princess of the Prince Sadanaru Toshiko (a daughter of Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Takahito), nyobo (court ladies) Chiyoko KONO, and nyobo (court ladies) Naetsuko MASUYAMA (增山奈越子).
Wife: Princess of the Prince Sadanaru Toshiko (a daughter of Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Takahito), nyobo (court ladies) Chiyoko KONO, and nyobo Naetsuko MASUYAMA.
sen.cmt: 二つ目の (court ladies) を削除しました。
